facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2411 of 1972 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 2411 of 1972. Appeal under s. 116-A of the Representation of the People Act from the judgment and order dated September 22, 1972 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court at Jabalpur in Election Petition No. 49, of 1972.

facts.text: Appeal under section 116-A of the Representation of the People Act.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under s. 116-A of the Representation of the People Act from the judgment and order dated September 22, 1972 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court at Jabalpur in Election Petition No. 49, of 1972. Pramodh Swarup, for the, appellant.

facts.text: Judgment and order dated September 22, 1972 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court at Jabalpur in Election Petition No. 49 of 1972.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and order dated September 22, 1972 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court at Jabalpur in Election Petition No. 49, of 1972. Pramodh Swarup, for the, appellant. N. Dikshit and R. N. Dikshit, for respondents Nos. 1 5.

facts.text: Election Petition No. 49 of 1972 filed in Madhya Pradesh High Court at Jabalpur.

anchor.surface_text: High Court at Jabalpur in Election Petition No. 49, of 1972. Pramodh Swarup, for the, appellant. N. Dikshit and R. N. Dikshit, for respondents Nos. 1 5. K. Gambhir, for respondent No. 4 The Judgment of the Court was delivered by JAGANMOHAN REDDY, J.-

facts.text: High Court dismissed the election petition for failure to deposit security under section 117 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is against an order of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh by which the election petition filed by the appellant was dismissed for failure to deposit the security as required under s. 117 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951- 29 5 hereinafter called the Act.

facts.text: Elections held in 1972, respondents 1 to 5 were elected as members of Legislative Council of Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The facts in brief are, that for the elections held in 1972 respondents 1 to 5 were elected as members of Legislative Council of Madhya Pradesh. The appellant presented an election petition on June 26, 1972, but did number deposit Rs. 2000/security as required under s. 117 of the Act,

facts.text: Appellant presented election petition on June 26, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant presented an election petition on June 26, 1972, but did number deposit Rs. 2000/security as required under s. 117 of the Act, which inter alia provides as follows Security for companyts.- 1  At the time of presenting an election petition, the petitioner shall deposit in the High Court

facts.text: Appellant did not deposit Rs. 2000 as security under section 117 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: but did number deposit Rs. 2000/security as required under s. 117 of the Act, which inter alia provides as follows Security for companyts.- 1  At the time of presenting an election petition, the petitioner shall deposit in the High Court in accordance with the rules of the High Court a sum of two thousand rupees as security for the companyts of the petition.

facts.text: Section 117 requires deposit of Rs. 2000 at time of presenting election petition.

anchor.surface_text: which inter alia provides as follows Security for companyts.- 1  At the time of presenting an election petition, the petitioner shall deposit in the High Court in accordance with the rules of the High Court a sum of two thousand rupees as security for the companyts of the petition. During the companyrse of the trial of an election petition, the High Court may, at any time, call upon the, petitioner to give such further security for companyts as it may direct.

facts.text: Petitioner contended before High Court that trial had not started and section 117 is directory not mandatory.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended before the High Court by the petitioner appellant that the trial had number started that s. 1 1 7 of the Act is only directory and number mandatory and that the deposit of Rs. 2000/- is only to secure the companyts in the companyrse of the trial of the election petition,

facts.text: High Court rejected petitioner's contentions and held section 117 mandatory.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected all these companytentions holding that it was mandatory for the petitioner when filing an election petition to deposit the amount of Rs. 2000/- under s. 117 of the Act and there is numberProvision under which a discretion was companyferred on the High Court to reduce the amount of security deposit as prayed for by him.

facts.text: High Court has power under sub-section 2 of section 117 to call for further security but not to reduce or dispense with initial deposit.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court referred to sub-s.  2  of s. 117 under which the High Court has been empowered to call upon the petitioner to give such further security for companyts as it may direct, which clearly indicates that while there is a pro- vision empowering the High Court to call upon the petitioner to give such further security for companyts,

facts.text: Supreme Court holds High Court was right that it cannot reduce or dispense with security deposit under section 117.

anchor.surface_text: We think the High Court was right in holding that it is number companypetent to reduce the amount of security deposit or to dispense with it.

facts.text: Petitioner contended that petition can only be dismissed after trial commenced by issuance of notices.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended before us that the petition can only be dismissed after the trial companymenced and the trial companymences only after numberices are issued to the respondents.

facts.text: Act amended by Act 47 of 1966, repealing sections including s.85.

anchor.surface_text: It is apparent that prior to repeat by Act 47 of 1966, s. 81 provided for the.presentation of the election petition by any candidate aggrieved by the result of the election to the Election Commission s. 83 prescribed what the companytents of the petition should be and s. 85 provided

facts.text: Prior to 1966 amendment, Election Commission could condone delay in presentation under proviso to s.85 but not non-compliance with s.117.

anchor.surface_text: Presentation of the petition under the repealed s. 81, beyond the period prescribed for its presentation companyld be companydoned by the Election Commission in its discretion under the proviso to the repealed s. 85 of the Act, but there is numberhing in s. 85 which permits the Election Commission to companydone the number-compliance with the provisions of s. 117.

facts.text: After 1966 amendment, jurisdiction transferred from Election Commission and Tribunals to High Courts.

anchor.surface_text: After the amendment, the jurisdiction of both the Election Commission and the Tribunal in respect of election disputes has been abolished and the High Courts of respective States have been vested with the jurisdiction in this regard.

facts.text: Right to challenge election provided by Article 329(b) of Constitution, statutory right requiring compliance with statute terms.

anchor.surface_text: The right to challenge an election is a right provided by Art. 329  b  of the Constitution of India, which provides that numberelection to either House of Parliament or to the House or either House of the Legislature of a State shall be called in question except by an election petition

facts.text: Petitioner relied on K. Kamaraja Nadar v. Kunju Thevar case for directory nature of s.117.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant the case of K. Kamaraja Nadar v. Kunju Thevar and Others  2   has been relied upon in support of the submission that the provisions of s. 117 of the Act are directory and number mandatory in their character.

facts.text: In K. Kamaraja Nadar case, deposit made but defective in head of account and favour, held sufficient compliance.

anchor.surface_text: That was a case under the unamended s. 117 of the Act under which the petitioner was required to enclose with the petition a Government Treasury receipt showing that a deposit of one thousand rupees had been made by him either in a Government Treasury or in the Reserve Bank of India in favour of the Secretary to the Election Commission as security for the companyts of the petition.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds non-deposit of security under s.117 leaves no option but to reject petition.

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of the view that the number-deposit of the security along with the election petition as required under s. 117 of the Act leaves numberoption to the Court but to reject it.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is accordingly dis- missed with companyts.

issues.text: Whether s. 117 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 is directory or mandatory?

anchor.surface_text: It was contended before the High Court by the petitioner appellant that the trial had not started that s. 117 of the Act is only directory and not mandatory and that the deposit of Rs. 2000/- is only to secure the costs in the course of the trial of the election petition,

issues.text: Whether the deposit of security under s. 117 is required at the time of presenting the election petition or only to secure costs during the course of the trial?

anchor.surface_text: It was contended before the High Court by the petitioner appellant that the trial had not started that s. 117 of the Act is only directory and not mandatory and that the deposit of Rs. 2000/- is only to secure the costs in the course of the trial of the election petition, as such dismissal of the petition for non-compliance with it is a penalty which is not one of the penalties prescribed under s. 118 of the Act.

issues.text: Whether dismissal of the election petition for non-compliance with s. 117 constitutes a penalty not prescribed under s. 118 of the Act?

anchor.surface_text: It was contended before the High Court by the petitioner appellant that the trial had not started that s. 117 of the Act is only directory and not mandatory and that the deposit of Rs. 2000/- is only to secure the costs in the course of the trial of the election petition,

issues.text: Whether the High Court has discretion to reduce the amount of security deposit or dispense with the requirement under s. 117?

anchor.surface_text: We think the High Court was right in holding that it is not competent to reduce the amount of security deposit or to dispense with it.

issues.text: Whether an election petition can only be dismissed after the trial has commenced by issuance of notices to respondents?

anchor.surface_text: It was contended before us that the petition can only be dismissed after the trial commenced and the trial commences only after notices are issued to the respondents. In support of this proposition, provisions of the repealed s. 85 of the Act are referred to.

issues.text: Whether the provisions of the repealed s. 85 of the Act permit condonation of non-compliance with s. 117 or require trial to commence before dismissal?

anchor.surface_text: It is apparent that prior to repeal by Act 47 of 1966, s. 81 provided for the presentation of the election petition by any candidate aggrieved by the result of the election to the Election Commission s. 83 prescribed what the contents of the petition should be and s. 85 provided

issues.text: Whether the marginal note to s. 86 'Trial of election petitions' prevents dismissal for non-compliance with s. 117 before issuance of notice?

anchor.surface_text: The argument of the appellants advocate that in view of the marginal note to s. 86 election petition can only be dismissed after the trial has commenced by the issue of a notice to the respondent is equally without substance. Amended s. 86 apart from sub-s. (1) provides for several matters in sub ss. (2) to (7) such as for reference of the election petition or election petitions, where there is more than one in respect of the same election, to a Judge, the ordering of security for costs in case of the application by a candidate who is not already a respondent being made a respondent, the permission to amend or amplify particulars of any corrupt practice alleged in the petition, the continuance of the trial of the election petition from day to day and its expeditious trial to be concluded as, far as possible within six months from the presentation of the petition to the High Court.

issues.text: Whether non-deposit of security under s. 117 leaves no option to the court but to dismiss the election petition?

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of the view that the non-deposit of the security along with the election petition as required under s. 117 of the Act leaves no option to the Court but to reject it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 117(1) mandates deposit at presentation; sub-section (2) allows only further security, no provision for waiver or reduction of initial deposit.

holdings.text: The non-deposit of the security along with the election petition as required under s. 117 of the Act leaves no option to the Court but to reject it.

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of the view that the number-deposit of the security along with the election petition as required under s. 117 of the Act leaves numberoption to the Court but to reject it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Strict compliance required for statutory right under Art. 329(b); no equity discretion; s.117 mandatory leads to dismissal under s.86(1).

holdings.text: Section 117 of the Act is mandatory and not directory.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected all these companytentions holding that it was mandatory for the petitioner when filing an election petition to deposit the amount of Rs. 2000/- under s. 117 of the Act and there is numberProvision under which a discretion was companyferred on the High Court to reduce the amount of security deposit as prayed for by him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court holding affirmed; plain language requires deposit at filing; petitioner's directory contention rejected.

holdings.text: The deposit under s. 117 is required at the time of presenting the election petition, not only during trial.

anchor.surface_text: which inter alia provides as follows Security for companyts.- 1  At the time of presenting an election petition, the petitioner shall deposit in the High Court in accordance with the rules of the High Court a sum of two thousand rupees as security for the companyts of the petition. During the companyrse of the trial of an election petition, the High Court may, at any time, call upon the, petitioner to give such further security for companyts as it may direct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit text of s.117(1); sub-s.(2) distinguishes further security during trial.

holdings.text: Dismissal for non-compliance with s.117 is not an unlisted penalty under s.118.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mandatory provision; dismissal follows directly from non-compliance, not as penalty.

holdings.text: An election petition can be dismissed for non-compliance before trial commences or notices issued.

anchor.surface_text: The argument of the appellants advocate that in view of the marginal numbere to s. 86 election petition can only be dismissed after the trial has companymenced by the issue of a numberice to the respondent is equally without substance. Amended s. 86 apart from sub-s.  1  provides for several matters in sub ss.  2  to  7  such as for reference of the election petition or election petitions, where there is more than one in respect of the same election, to a Judge, the ordering of security for companyts in case of the application by a candidate who is number already a respondent being made a respondent, the permission to amend or amplify particulars of any companyrupt practice alleged in the petition, the companytinuance of the trial of the election petition from day to day and its expeditious trial to be companycluded as, far as possible within six months from the presentation of the petition to the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.86(1) allows dismissal for non-compliance with ss.81,83,117 before notice; marginal note does not control clear text.

holdings.text: Repealed s.85 does not permit condonation of non-compliance with s.117.

anchor.surface_text: Presentation of the petition under the repealed s. 81, beyond the period prescribed for its presentation companyld be companydoned by the Election Commission in its discretion under the proviso to the repealed s. 85 of the Act, but there is numberhing in s. 85 which permits the Election Commission to companydone the number-compliance with the provisions of s. 117.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso to s.85 condones only delay under s.81, not s.117 non-compliance.

holdings.text: Marginal note to s.86 does not require trial commencement before dismissal for non-compliance.

anchor.surface_text: The marginal numbere of s. 86, namely, Trial of election petitions does number indicate that under sub-s.  1  of s. 86 an election petition cannot be dismissed for number-compliance with the provisions set out therein, unless numberice is issued to the respondent. Where the language is clear and can admit of numberother meaning such as is evidence from sub-s.  1  of s. 86, the marginal cannot be read, to companytrol that- power.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Marginal notes do not control clear statutory language; s.86(1) permits early dismissal.

holdings.text: Right to challenge election is purely statutory requiring strict compliance; no common law right or equity discretion.

anchor.surface_text: The right to challenge an election is a right provided by Art. 329  b  of the Constitution of India, which provides that numberelection to either House of Parliament or to the House or either House of the Legislature of a State shall be called in question except by an election petition presented to such authority and in such manner as may be provided for by or under any law made by the appropriate Legislature. The right companyferred being a statutory right, the terms of that statute had to be companyplied with. There is numberquestion of any companymon law right to challenge an election.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.329(b) creates statutory right governed by RPA terms; no inherent discretion.

precedents.citation: N. P. Ponnuswami v. Returning Officer, Namekkal Constituency and Others 1

anchor.surface_text: N. P. Ponnuswami v. Returning Officer, Namekkal Constituency and Others 1 it was pointed out that strictly speaking, it is the sole right of the Legislature to examine and determine all matters relating to the election of its own members, and if the Legislature takes it out of its own hands and vests in a special tribunal an entirely new and unknown jurisdiction, that special jurisdiction should be exercised in accordance with the law which creates it.

precedents.case_name: N. P. Ponnuswami v. Returning Officer, Namakkal Constituency and Others
precedents.cited_proposition: special jurisdiction for election disputes should be exercised strictly in accordance with the law which creates it; right to vote or stand for election is statutory and subject to its limitations
precedents.cited_holding: strictly speaking, it is the sole right of the Legislature to examine and determine all matters relating to the election of its own members, and if the Legislature takes it out of its own hands and vests in a special tribunal an entirely new and unknown jurisdiction, that special jurisdiction should be exercised in accordance with the law which creates it.

precedents.citation: K. Kamaraja Nadar v. Kunju Thevar and Others 2

anchor.surface_text: K. Kamaraja Nadar v. Kunju Thevar and Others 2   has been relied upon in support of the submission that the provisions of s. 117 of the Act are directory and number mandatory in their character.

precedents.case_name: K. Kamaraja Nadar v. Kunju Thevar and Others
precedents.cited_proposition: provisions of s. 117 requiring deposit in favour of Secretary to Election Commission are directory, not mandatory; essence is furnishing security for costs
precedents.cited_holding: the words in favour of the Secretary to the Election Commission used in s. 117 are directory and number mandatory in their character. What is of the essence of the provision contained in s. 117 is that the petitioner should furnish security for the costs of the petition

precedents.citation: Lalaram v. The Supreme Court of India and Others , AIR 1967 SC 847

anchor.surface_text: Lalaram v. The Supreme Court of India and Others ,  has numberrelevance to the matter in issue because as pointed out by the High Court that case relates to security being furnished for filing a review petition under the Supreme Court Rules, which stands on a different footing. AIR 1967 SC 847

precedents.case_name: Lalaram v. The Supreme Court of India and Others
precedents.cited_proposition: security being furnished for filing a review petition under the Supreme Court Rules
